sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: The CSS Color Module Level 4 specification defined a slew of new color features when it became a candidate recommendation in 2022, including Oklab and Oklch, which have widened the field of color we have to work with. Explore the Oklch color space and how to start using it in CSS today.
articles.title: Falling For Oklch: A Love Story Of Color Spaces, Gamuts, And CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andy Budd)
articles.description: The so-called “Double Diamond” is a great way of visualizing an ideal design process — but it’s just not the way most companies deliver new projects or services. Andy Budd proposes a new “Double Diamond” idea that better aligns with the way work actually gets done and highlights the place where design has the most leverage.
articles.title: Improving The Double Diamond Design Process

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Preethi Sam)
articles.description: We often think of shadows in CSS as something to reach for when we want to add depth to a design. But shadows can be used for more than depth. Let’s experiment with different shadows — two CSS properties and a filter — to make interesting hover effects, different text styles, and even casting shadows on other shadows.
articles.title: A Few Interesting Ways To Use CSS Shadows For More Than Depth

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Costa Alexoglou)
articles.description: Discover how to improve the user experience of nested menus and tackle a minor yet common issue with them when the user’s pointer leaves the menu item for a moment, and the nested menu goes away, requiring the user to re-hover and try again. A well-known concept called the “safe triangle” solves this problem.
articles.title: Better Context Menus With Safe Triangles

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mike Herchel)
articles.description: The background image used in the hero component, which is slow to load, is a very common problem with any component that uses a large image file as a background image. In this article, Mike Herchel walks you through how to tackle this common performance issue using modern techniques.
articles.title: Modern Methods For Improving Drupal’s Largest Contentful Paint Core Web Vital

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lars Kappert)
articles.description: Most of the projects have at least a few unused files, exports, and dependencies lying around, often because it’s difficult knowing when one thing relies on another and scary removing something you’re not sure is in use. Lars Kappert shares a tool he’s been working on that offers a solution.
articles.title: Knip: An Automated Tool For Finding Unused Files, Exports, And Dependencies

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Hannah Milan)
articles.description: In part 2 of the series, Hannah Milan reviews various accessible text over images techniques for designing your content, including framing the image, soft-colored gradients technique, text styles and text position, solid color shapes, and use of colored backgrounds.
articles.title: Designing Accessible Text Over Images: Best Practices, Techniques And Resources (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: What does your performance “stack” look like? There are all kinds of tools available for measuring page speed, but what data and assumptions do they use to measure performance? And speaking of *measuring* performance, there’s quite a difference between that and *monitoring* performance. Let’s dig in!
articles.title: Running A Page Speed Test: Monitoring vs. Measuring

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Maximillian Piras)
articles.description: Friction often has a negative connotation in user experience design, but it actually has many benefits. Its best-known use case is mitigating unintended consequences in high-risk scenarios, yet it has a new place in the age of artificial intelligence. Adding strategic friction to interfaces can lead to profound efficiency gains in machine learning algorithms.
articles.title: Using Friction As A Feature In Machine Learning Algorithms

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Hannah Milan)
articles.description: In this two-part series of articles, Hannah Milan covers the best practices when using various accessible text over images techniques for designing your web and mobile app content.
articles.title: Designing Accessible Text Over Images: Best Practices, Techniques, And Resources (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Liran Cohen)
articles.description: Liran Cohen and the team at Bookaway, a travel booking service, dramatically improved their site’s performance by auditing Core Web Vitals. In this article, Liran shares his team’s process for auditing and monitoring Web Vitals and the effort it took to dramatically improve Bookaway’s performance — and the benefits that came with it.
articles.title: How We Optimized Performance To Serve A Global Audience

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: We’re talking about headless content management systems. What are they, and how do they differ from more traditional systems? Drew McLellan talks to Alvin Bryan to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 64 With Alvin Bryan: What Is A Headless CMS?

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: The OWASP API Security Top 10 is a standard reference guide highlighting the most critical web API vulnerabilities to help developers and organizations understand and mitigate potential security threats. We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you about each security risk and techniques to
articles.title: OWASP API Security Top 10 – Secure Your APIs

articles.author: Gideon Akinsanmi
articles.description: An online image-to-PDF converter is a website that helps you convert your images to PDFs. This tool is useful because it provides an efficient way to store your images. In this tutorial, you'll learn how you can create your online image-to-pdf converter with HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and NodeJS. Table of
articles.title: How to Build an Online Image-to-PDF Converter with HTML, CSS, JS, and NodeJS

articles.author: Abbey Rennemeyer
articles.description: The freeCodeCamp community has published more than 10,000 tutorials over the years. But lately we've focused on creating even longer resources for learning math, programming, and computer science. This is why we've created freeCodeCamp Press – a division of freeCodeCamp where we publish full-length books and handbooks – all available
articles.title: Introducing freeCodeCamp Press – Free Books for Developers

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: A lot of machine learning course relay on frameworks that abstract the inner workings of what is going on. If you want to become proficient, it is helpful to understand how things work under the hood. We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you
articles.title: Learn Machine Learning and Neural Networks without Frameworks

articles.author: Adekola Olawale
articles.description: In the fast-paced and ever-evolving world of software development, there's always a need for flexibility, adaptability, and responsiveness. Traditional software development methods often struggled to keep up with changing requirements and market demands. This can lead to delays, cost overruns, and dissatisfied stakeholders. In response to these challenges, the Agile
articles.title: Agile Software Development Handbook – Scrum, Kanban, and Other Methodologies Explained

articles.author: Arunachalam B
articles.description: In the rapidly evolving world of mobile app development, Flutter has gained immense popularity for its ability to create stunning and high-performance apps across multiple platforms.  Flutter's framework allows developers to build beautiful user interfaces, deliver native performance, and streamline development.  In this tutorial, I will walk you
articles.title: How to Build and Release a Flutter App in Google Play

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: C is one of the oldest, most widely known, and most influential programming languages. It is used in many industries because it is a highly flexible and powerful language. Learning C is a worthwhile endeavor – no matter your starting point or aspirations – because it builds a solid foundation
articles.title: The C Programming Handbook for Beginners

articles.author: Chinenye Anikwenze
articles.description: Imagine this situation: you are working on a time-sensitive project, and you need to implement some specific UI components that comply with accessibility best practices.  You may know about some libraries that are full of pre-designed UI elements, each with their own style. But here's the catch – you
articles.title: How to Use Un-Styled UI Components – Guide for Front-End Developers

articles.author: Krish Jaiswal
articles.description: Hello everyone 👋 In this tutorial, you'll learn how to make a simple Task Manager CLI (Command Line Interface) tool. This means you can use commands to Create, View, Update, or Delete your todos.  We will be building this CLI tool using NodeJS. We'll also use MongoDB as the
articles.title: How to Build a Task Manager CLI Tool with Node.js

articles.author: Grant Weatherston
articles.description: When it comes to handling dates and times in JavaScript, developers often find themselves grappling with the complexities of the built-in Date object. While vanilla JavaScript provides fundamental functionality, it can be quite cumbersome to work with, especially when dealing with parsing, formatting, and manipulating dates. This is where external
articles.title: JavaScript Dates – How to Use the DayJS Library to work with Date and Time in JS
